Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At some point between 
the 1st and 5th century CE, the Hindu sage Patañjali began to codify
the ancient, meditative traditions practiced throughout India. He recorded techniques nearly as old 
as Indian civilization itself in 196 manuals called the Yoga Sutras. These texts defined yoga as the ‘yoking’ 
or restraining of the mind from focusing on external objects in efforts to reach a state 
of pure consciousness. Over time, yoga came to incorporate
physical elements from gymnastics and wrestling. Today, there are a multitude of approaches
to modern yoga— though most still maintain the three core
elements of Patañjali’s practice: physical postures, breathing exercises, 
and spiritual contemplation. This blend of physical 
and mental exercise is widely believed to have a unique set 
of health advantages. Such as improving strength
and flexibility, boosting heart and lung function, 
and enhancing psychological well-being. But what have contemporary studies shown
regarding the benefits of this ancient tradition? Despite attempts by many researchers, it's tough to make specific claims 
about yoga's advantages. Its unique combination of activities 
makes it difficult to determine which component is producing 
a specific health benefit. Additionally, yoga studies are often 
made up of small sample sizes that lack diversity, and the heavy reliance on self-reporting
makes results subjective. However, there are some health benefits that have more robust scientific 
support than others. Let’s start with flexibility and strength. Twisting your body 
into yoga’s physical postures stretches multiple muscle groups. In the short term, stretching can change
the water content of these muscles, ligaments, and tendons 
to make them more elastic. Over time, regular stretching 
stimulates stem cells which then differentiate 
into new muscle tissue and other cells that generate 
elastic collagen. Frequent stretching also reduces 
the body’s natural reflex to constrict muscles, improving your pain tolerance 
for feats of flexibility. Researchers haven’t found 
that any one form of yoga improves flexibility more than another, so the impact of specific 
postures is unclear. But like other low-impact exercises, yoga reliably improves fitness 
and flexibility in healthy populations. The practice has also been shown to be
a potentially powerful therapeutic tool. In studies involving patients with 
a variety of musculo-skeletal disorders, yoga was more helpful at reducing pain 
and improving mobility than other forms of low-impact exercise. Adding yoga to an existing 
exercise routine can improve strength and flexibility for hard to treat 
conditions like chronic lower back pain, rheumatoid arthritis, and osteoporosis. Yoga’s mix of physical exercise 
and regimented breathing has proven similarly therapeutic 
for lung health. Lung diseases like chronic bronchitis, 
emphysema, and asthma shrink the passageways that carry oxygen, while weakening the membrane 
that brings oxygen into the blood. But breathing exercises 
like those found in yoga relax the muscles constricting 
those passageways and improve oxygen diffusion. Increasing the blood’s oxygen content
is especially helpful for those with weak heart muscles who have difficulty pumping
enough oxygen throughout the body. And for those with healthy hearts, this practice can lower blood pressure
and reduce risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Yoga’s most widely celebrated benefit
may be the most difficult to prove: its psychological effects. Despite the longstanding association 
between yoga and psychological wellbeing, there’s little conclusive evidence 
on how the practice affects mental health. One of the biggest claims is that yoga improves symptoms 
of depression and anxiety disorders. Since diagnosis of these conditions
varies widely as do their origin and severity,
it’s difficult to quantify yoga’s impact. However, there is evidence to suggest that yoga can help reduce 
the symptoms of stress, as well as meditation or relaxation. Research on the effects 
of yoga is still evolving. In the future, we’ll need larger studies, 
incorporating diverse participants, which can measure yoga’s impact
on heart attacks, cancer rates, cognitive function and more. But for now, yoga can continue 
its ancient tradition as a way to exercise, reflect, and relax.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The origins of Yoga can be traced back to which ancient scholar?
Options: A. Plato, B. Sushruta, C. Patanjali, D. Zhang Sanfen
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with codifying the ancient meditative traditions practiced throughout India? Options: A. Patañjali, B. B.K.S. Iyengar, C. Swami Satchidananda, D. Paramahansa Yogananda Correct Option: A
Question 2: What are the three core elements of Patañjali's yoga practice? Options: A. Physical postures, breathing exercises, and spiritual contemplation, B. Meditation, pranayama, and asana, C. Mantra, mudra, and bandha, D. Pranayama, asana, and meditation Correct Option: A
Question 3: According to the transcript, which of the following health benefits of yoga has more robust scientific support? Options: A. Improved strength and flexibility, B. Enhanced psychological well-being, C. Reduced pain and improved mobility, D. Improved lung function Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the potential therapeutic tool that yoga has been shown to be in studies involving patients with musculo-skeletal disorders? Options: A. Improved strength and flexibility, B. Reduced pain and improved mobility, C. Enhanced psychological well-being, D. Improved lung function Correct Option: B
Question 5: How does yoga's mix of physical exercise and regimented breathing have proven therapeutic for lung health? Options: A. By relaxing the muscles constricting the passageways that carry oxygen, B. By increasing the blood's oxygen content, C. By improving oxygen diffusion, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the biggest challenge in determining the benefits of yoga, according to the transcript? Options: A. The unique combination of activities makes it difficult to determine which component is producing a specific health benefit, B. The small sample sizes and lack of diversity in yoga studies, C. The subjective nature of self-reporting in yoga studies, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the current state of evidence regarding the impact of yoga on heart attacks and cancer rates? Options: A. There is conclusive evidence that yoga can prevent heart attacks and cancer, B. There is evidence to suggest that yoga can help reduce the risk of heart attacks and cancer, C. There is no conclusive evidence on the impact of yoga on heart attacks and cancer, D. Yoga has no impact on heart attacks and cancer Correct Option: C
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the most widely celebrated benefit of yoga? Options: A. Improved strength and flexibility, B. Enhanced psychological well-being, C. Reduced pain and improved mobility, D. Improved lung function Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the role of stem cells in the development of new muscle tissue and elastic collagen, according to the transcript? Options: A. Stem cells differentiate into new muscle tissue and other cells that generate elastic collagen, B. Stem cells stimulate the growth of new muscle tissue and elastic collagen, C. The role of stem cells is unclear, D. Stem cells have no role in the development of new muscle tissue and elastic collagen Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the potential benefit of yoga for those with weak heart muscles? Options: A. Improved strength and flexibility, B. Enhanced psychological well-being, C. Increased oxygen diffusion, D. Increased blood's oxygen content Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the ancient scholar who is credited with codifying the ancient meditative traditions practiced throughout India. The correct option in both questions is Patañjali. The options in Question 1 are more specific to the context of yoga, making it a more relevant and accurate match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At some point between 
the 1st and 5th century CE, the Hindu sage Patañjali began to codify
the ancient, meditative traditions practiced throughout India. He recorded techniques nearly as old 
as Indian civilization itself in 196 manuals called the Yoga Sutras. These texts defined yoga as the ‘yoking’ 
or restraining of the mind from focusing on external objects in efforts to reach a state 
of pure consciousness. Over time, yoga came to incorporate
physical elements from gymnastics and wrestling. Today, there are a multitude of approaches
to modern yoga— though most still maintain the three core
elements of Patañjali’s practice: physical postures, breathing exercises, 
and spiritual contemplation. This blend of physical 
and mental exercise is widely believed to have a unique set 
of health advantages. Such as improving strength
and flexibility, boosting heart and lung function, 
and enhancing psychological well-being. But what have contemporary studies shown
regarding the benefits of this ancient tradition? Despite attempts by many researchers, it's tough to make specific claims 
about yoga's advantages. Its unique combination of activities 
makes it difficult to determine which component is producing 
a specific health benefit. Additionally, yoga studies are often 
made up of small sample sizes that lack diversity, and the heavy reliance on self-reporting
makes results subjective. However, there are some health benefits that have more robust scientific 
support than others. Let’s start with flexibility and strength. Twisting your body 
into yoga’s physical postures stretches multiple muscle groups. In the short term, stretching can change
the water content of these muscles, ligaments, and tendons 
to make them more elastic. Over time, regular stretching 
stimulates stem cells which then differentiate 
into new muscle tissue and other cells that generate 
elastic collagen. Frequent stretching also reduces 
the body’s natural reflex to constrict muscles, improving your pain tolerance 
for feats of flexibility. Researchers haven’t found 
that any one form of yoga improves flexibility more than another, so the impact of specific 
postures is unclear. But like other low-impact exercises, yoga reliably improves fitness 
and flexibility in healthy populations. The practice has also been shown to be
a potentially powerful therapeutic tool. In studies involving patients with 
a variety of musculo-skeletal disorders, yoga was more helpful at reducing pain 
and improving mobility than other forms of low-impact exercise. Adding yoga to an existing 
exercise routine can improve strength and flexibility for hard to treat 
conditions like chronic lower back pain, rheumatoid arthritis, and osteoporosis. Yoga’s mix of physical exercise 
and regimented breathing has proven similarly therapeutic 
for lung health. Lung diseases like chronic bronchitis, 
emphysema, and asthma shrink the passageways that carry oxygen, while weakening the membrane 
that brings oxygen into the blood. But breathing exercises 
like those found in yoga relax the muscles constricting 
those passageways and improve oxygen diffusion. Increasing the blood’s oxygen content
is especially helpful for those with weak heart muscles who have difficulty pumping
enough oxygen throughout the body. And for those with healthy hearts, this practice can lower blood pressure
and reduce risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Yoga’s most widely celebrated benefit
may be the most difficult to prove: its psychological effects. Despite the longstanding association 
between yoga and psychological wellbeing, there’s little conclusive evidence 
on how the practice affects mental health. One of the biggest claims is that yoga improves symptoms 
of depression and anxiety disorders. Since diagnosis of these conditions
varies widely as do their origin and severity,
it’s difficult to quantify yoga’s impact. However, there is evidence to suggest that yoga can help reduce 
the symptoms of stress, as well as meditation or relaxation. Research on the effects 
of yoga is still evolving. In the future, we’ll need larger studies, 
incorporating diverse participants, which can measure yoga’s impact
on heart attacks, cancer rates, cognitive function and more. But for now, yoga can continue 
its ancient tradition as a way to exercise, reflect, and relax.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The core elements of traditional yogic practice include all of the following except which one?
Options: A. Physical postures, B. Herbal infusions, C. Spiritual contemplation, D. Breathing exercises
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At some point between 
the 1st and 5th century CE, the Hindu sage Patañjali began to codify
the ancient, meditative traditions practiced throughout India. He recorded techniques nearly as old 
as Indian civilization itself in 196 manuals called the Yoga Sutras. These texts defined yoga as the ‘yoking’ 
or restraining of the mind from focusing on external objects in efforts to reach a state 
of pure consciousness. Over time, yoga came to incorporate
physical elements from gymnastics and wrestling. Today, there are a multitude of approaches
to modern yoga— though most still maintain the three core
elements of Patañjali’s practice: physical postures, breathing exercises, 
and spiritual contemplation. This blend of physical 
and mental exercise is widely believed to have a unique set 
of health advantages. Such as improving strength
and flexibility, boosting heart and lung function, 
and enhancing psychological well-being. But what have contemporary studies shown
regarding the benefits of this ancient tradition? Despite attempts by many researchers, it's tough to make specific claims 
about yoga's advantages. Its unique combination of activities 
makes it difficult to determine which component is producing 
a specific health benefit. Additionally, yoga studies are often 
made up of small sample sizes that lack diversity, and the heavy reliance on self-reporting
makes results subjective. However, there are some health benefits that have more robust scientific 
support than others. Let’s start with flexibility and strength. Twisting your body 
into yoga’s physical postures stretches multiple muscle groups. In the short term, stretching can change
the water content of these muscles, ligaments, and tendons 
to make them more elastic. Over time, regular stretching 
stimulates stem cells which then differentiate 
into new muscle tissue and other cells that generate 
elastic collagen. Frequent stretching also reduces 
the body’s natural reflex to constrict muscles, improving your pain tolerance 
for feats of flexibility. Researchers haven’t found 
that any one form of yoga improves flexibility more than another, so the impact of specific 
postures is unclear. But like other low-impact exercises, yoga reliably improves fitness 
and flexibility in healthy populations. The practice has also been shown to be
a potentially powerful therapeutic tool. In studies involving patients with 
a variety of musculo-skeletal disorders, yoga was more helpful at reducing pain 
and improving mobility than other forms of low-impact exercise. Adding yoga to an existing 
exercise routine can improve strength and flexibility for hard to treat 
conditions like chronic lower back pain, rheumatoid arthritis, and osteoporosis. Yoga’s mix of physical exercise 
and regimented breathing has proven similarly therapeutic 
for lung health. Lung diseases like chronic bronchitis, 
emphysema, and asthma shrink the passageways that carry oxygen, while weakening the membrane 
that brings oxygen into the blood. But breathing exercises 
like those found in yoga relax the muscles constricting 
those passageways and improve oxygen diffusion. Increasing the blood’s oxygen content
is especially helpful for those with weak heart muscles who have difficulty pumping
enough oxygen throughout the body. And for those with healthy hearts, this practice can lower blood pressure
and reduce risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Yoga’s most widely celebrated benefit
may be the most difficult to prove: its psychological effects. Despite the longstanding association 
between yoga and psychological wellbeing, there’s little conclusive evidence 
on how the practice affects mental health. One of the biggest claims is that yoga improves symptoms 
of depression and anxiety disorders. Since diagnosis of these conditions
varies widely as do their origin and severity,
it’s difficult to quantify yoga’s impact. However, there is evidence to suggest that yoga can help reduce 
the symptoms of stress, as well as meditation or relaxation. Research on the effects 
of yoga is still evolving. In the future, we’ll need larger studies, 
incorporating diverse participants, which can measure yoga’s impact
on heart attacks, cancer rates, cognitive function and more. But for now, yoga can continue 
its ancient tradition as a way to exercise, reflect, and relax.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Research into yoga is limited by which of the following?
Options: A. Small sample sizes, B. Lack of diversity, C. Reliance on self-reporting, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

The options for Question 6 also match the ground truth MCQ, with option D being the correct answer, stating that the unique combination of activities, small sample sizes, lack of diversity, and subjective nature of self-reporting all contribute to the limitations of yoga research.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At some point between 
the 1st and 5th century CE, the Hindu sage Patañjali began to codify
the ancient, meditative traditions practiced throughout India. He recorded techniques nearly as old 
as Indian civilization itself in 196 manuals called the Yoga Sutras. These texts defined yoga as the ‘yoking’ 
or restraining of the mind from focusing on external objects in efforts to reach a state 
of pure consciousness. Over time, yoga came to incorporate
physical elements from gymnastics and wrestling. Today, there are a multitude of approaches
to modern yoga— though most still maintain the three core
elements of Patañjali’s practice: physical postures, breathing exercises, 
and spiritual contemplation. This blend of physical 
and mental exercise is widely believed to have a unique set 
of health advantages. Such as improving strength
and flexibility, boosting heart and lung function, 
and enhancing psychological well-being. But what have contemporary studies shown
regarding the benefits of this ancient tradition? Despite attempts by many researchers, it's tough to make specific claims 
about yoga's advantages. Its unique combination of activities 
makes it difficult to determine which component is producing 
a specific health benefit. Additionally, yoga studies are often 
made up of small sample sizes that lack diversity, and the heavy reliance on self-reporting
makes results subjective. However, there are some health benefits that have more robust scientific 
support than others. Let’s start with flexibility and strength. Twisting your body 
into yoga’s physical postures stretches multiple muscle groups. In the short term, stretching can change
the water content of these muscles, ligaments, and tendons 
to make them more elastic. Over time, regular stretching 
stimulates stem cells which then differentiate 
into new muscle tissue and other cells that generate 
elastic collagen. Frequent stretching also reduces 
the body’s natural reflex to constrict muscles, improving your pain tolerance 
for feats of flexibility. Researchers haven’t found 
that any one form of yoga improves flexibility more than another, so the impact of specific 
postures is unclear. But like other low-impact exercises, yoga reliably improves fitness 
and flexibility in healthy populations. The practice has also been shown to be
a potentially powerful therapeutic tool. In studies involving patients with 
a variety of musculo-skeletal disorders, yoga was more helpful at reducing pain 
and improving mobility than other forms of low-impact exercise. Adding yoga to an existing 
exercise routine can improve strength and flexibility for hard to treat 
conditions like chronic lower back pain, rheumatoid arthritis, and osteoporosis. Yoga’s mix of physical exercise 
and regimented breathing has proven similarly therapeutic 
for lung health. Lung diseases like chronic bronchitis, 
emphysema, and asthma shrink the passageways that carry oxygen, while weakening the membrane 
that brings oxygen into the blood. But breathing exercises 
like those found in yoga relax the muscles constricting 
those passageways and improve oxygen diffusion. Increasing the blood’s oxygen content
is especially helpful for those with weak heart muscles who have difficulty pumping
enough oxygen throughout the body. And for those with healthy hearts, this practice can lower blood pressure
and reduce risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Yoga’s most widely celebrated benefit
may be the most difficult to prove: its psychological effects. Despite the longstanding association 
between yoga and psychological wellbeing, there’s little conclusive evidence 
on how the practice affects mental health. One of the biggest claims is that yoga improves symptoms 
of depression and anxiety disorders. Since diagnosis of these conditions
varies widely as do their origin and severity,
it’s difficult to quantify yoga’s impact. However, there is evidence to suggest that yoga can help reduce 
the symptoms of stress, as well as meditation or relaxation. Research on the effects 
of yoga is still evolving. In the future, we’ll need larger studies, 
incorporating diverse participants, which can measure yoga’s impact
on heart attacks, cancer rates, cognitive function and more. But for now, yoga can continue 
its ancient tradition as a way to exercise, reflect, and relax.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following statements about yoga is NOT true?
Options: A. Yoga prevents certain cancers from recurring, B. Its practice was originally described in texts called the Yoga Sutras, C. Yoga improves strength and flexibility, D. Stress reduction can be achieved through yoga
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with codifying the ancient meditative traditions practiced throughout India? Options: A. Patañjali, B. B.K.S. Iyengar, C. Swami Satchidananda, D. Paramahansa Yogananda Correct Option: A
Question 2: What are the three core elements of Patañjali's yoga practice? Options: A. Physical postures, breathing exercises, and spiritual contemplation, B. Meditation, pranayama, and asana, C. Mantra, mudra, and bandha, D. Pranayama, asana, and meditation Correct Option: A
Question 3: According to the transcript, which of the following health benefits of yoga has more robust scientific support? Options: A. Improved strength and flexibility, B. Enhanced psychological well-being, C. Reduced pain and improved mobility, D. Improved lung function Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the potential therapeutic tool that yoga has been shown to be in studies involving patients with musculo-skeletal disorders? Options: A. Improved strength and flexibility, B. Reduced pain and improved mobility, C. Enhanced psychological well-being, D. Improved lung function Correct Option: B
Question 5: How does yoga's mix of physical exercise and regimented breathing have proven therapeutic for lung health? Options: A. By relaxing the muscles constricting the passageways that carry oxygen, B. By increasing the blood's oxygen content, C. By improving oxygen diffusion, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the biggest challenge in determining the benefits of yoga, according to the transcript? Options: A. The unique combination of activities makes it difficult to determine which component is producing a specific health benefit, B. The small sample sizes and lack of diversity in yoga studies, C. The subjective nature of self-reporting in yoga studies, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the current state of evidence regarding the impact of yoga on heart attacks and cancer rates? Options: A. There is conclusive evidence that yoga can prevent heart attacks and cancer, B. There is evidence to suggest that yoga can help reduce the risk of heart attacks and cancer, C. There is no conclusive evidence on the impact of yoga on heart attacks and cancer, D. Yoga has no impact on heart attacks and cancer Correct Option: C
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the most widely celebrated benefit of yoga? Options: A. Improved strength and flexibility, B. Enhanced psychological well-being, C. Reduced pain and improved mobility, D. Improved lung function Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the role of stem cells in the development of new muscle tissue and elastic collagen, according to the transcript? Options: A. Stem cells differentiate into new muscle tissue and other cells that generate elastic collagen, B. Stem cells stimulate the growth of new muscle tissue and elastic collagen, C. The role of stem cells is unclear, D. Stem cells have no role in the development of new muscle tissue and elastic collagen Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the potential benefit of yoga for those with weak heart muscles? Options: A. Improved strength and flexibility, B. Enhanced psychological well-being, C. Increased oxygen diffusion, D. Increased blood's oxygen content Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 7 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

The ground truth MCQ asks which statement about yoga is NOT true, and the correct option is "Yoga prevents certain cancers from recurring." Question 7 asks about the current state of evidence regarding the impact of yoga on heart attacks and cancer rates, and the correct option is "There is no conclusive evidence on the impact of yoga on heart attacks and cancer."

Although the questions are not identical, they both address the topic of yoga's impact on serious health conditions (cancer) and the limitations of current evidence. Therefore, I recommend:

**Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Steroids: they’re infamous 
for their use in sports. But they’re also found in inhalers, 
creams to treat poison ivy and eczema, and shots to ease inflammation. The steroids in these medicines aren’t 
the same as the ones used to build muscle. In fact, they’re all based on 
yet another steroid— one our body produces naturally, 
and we can’t live without. Taking a step back, the reason 
there are so many different steroids is because the term refers to substances 
with a shared molecular structure, rather than shared effects on the body. Steroids can be naturally occurring 
or synthetic, but what all steroids have in common 
is a molecular structure that consists of a base of four rings 
made of 17 carbon atoms arranged in three hexagons 
and one pentagon. A molecule must contain 
this exact arrangement to be a steroid, though most also have side chains— additional atoms that can dramatically 
impact the molecule’s function. Steroids get their name 
from the fatty molecule cholesterol. In fact, our bodies make steroids 
out of cholesterol. That fatty cholesterol base 
means that steroids are able to cross fatty cell membranes 
and enter cells. Within the cell, they can directly 
influence gene expression and protein synthesis. This is different from many other types 
of signaling molecules, which can’t cross the cell membrane and have to create their effects 
from outside the cell, through more complicated pathways. So steroids can create their effects 
faster than those other molecules. Back to the steroids 
in anti-inflammatory medications: all of these are based on a naturally 
occurring steroid called cortisol. Cortisol is the body’s 
primary stress signal, and it has a huge range of functions. When we experience a stressor— anything from a fight with a friend, 
to spotting a bear, to an infection or low blood sugar— the brain reacts by sending a signal from 
the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland. The pituitary gland then sends a signal 
to the adrenal glands. The adrenal glands produce cortisol, 
and release some constantly. But when they receive the signal 
from the pituitary gland, they release a burst of cortisol, which spurs the body to generate 
more glucose for energy, decrease functions not immediately 
related to survival, like digestion, and can activate 
a fight-flight-or-freeze response. This is helpful in the short term, 
but can cause undesirable side effects like insomnia and lowered mood 
if they last too long. Cortisol also interacts 
with the immune system in complex ways— depending on the situation, it can increase or decrease 
certain immune functions. In the process of fighting infection, the immune system 
often creates inflammation. Cortisol suppresses the immune system’s 
ability to produce inflammation, which, again, 
can be useful in the short term. But too much cortisol 
can have negative impacts, like reducing the immune system’s ability 
to regenerate bone marrow and lymph nodes. To prevent levels 
from staying high for too long, cortisol suppresses the signal 
that causes the adrenal glands to release more cortisol. Medicinal corticosteroids channel 
cortisol’s effects on the immune system to fight allergic reactions, 
rashes, and asthma. All these things are forms 
of inflammation. There are many synthetic steroids 
that share the same basic mechanism: they enhance the body’s cortisol supply, which in turn shuts down 
the hyperactive immune responses that cause inflammation. These corticosteroids sneak into cells 
and can turn off the “fire alarm” by suppressing gene expression 
of inflammatory signals. The steroids in inhalers and creams impact
only the affected organ— the skin, or the lungs. Intravenous or oral versions, used 
to treat chronic autoimmune conditions like lupus or inflammatory bowel disease, 
impact the whole body. With these conditions, the body’s 
immune system attacks its own cells, a process analogous to a constant 
asthma attack or rash. A constant low dose of steroids can help keep this renegade
immune response under control— but because of the negative psychological 
and physiological effects of longterm exposure, higher doses are reserved 
for emergencies and flare-ups. While an asthma attack, poison ivy welts, 
and irritable bowel syndrome might seem totally unrelated, 
they all have something in common: an immune response 
that’s doing more harm than good. And while corticosteroids 
won’t give you giant muscles, they can be the body’s best defense 
against itself.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In this particular study area, up to ____ percent of a grizzly bear’s diet is vegetation?
Options: A. 10, B. 70, C. 90, D. 40
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary source of steroids in the human body? Options: A. Fatty foods, B. Cholesterol, C. Sugar, D. Protein Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which part of the brain sends a signal to the pituitary gland in response to a stressor? Options: A. Hypothalamus, B. Pituitary gland, C. Adrenal glands, D. Brainstem Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the primary function of cortisol in the body's response to stress? Options: A. To build muscle, B. To regulate blood sugar levels, C. To respond to stress and trigger a fight-flight-or-freeze response, decrease non-essential functions, and interact with the immune system, D. To fight infection Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the effect of cortisol on the immune system in the short term? Options: A. It suppresses the immune system and reduces its ability to produce inflammation, B. It increases the immune system's ability to fight infection, C. It has no effect on the immune system, D. It activates a fight-flight-or-freeze response Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the primary difference between naturally occurring steroids and synthetic steroids? Options: A. Naturally occurring steroids are more effective, B. Synthetic steroids are more effective, C. Naturally occurring steroids are found in the body, while synthetic steroids are created in medications, D. Synthetic steroids are more expensive Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the effect of corticosteroids on the immune system in the short term? Options: A. It increases the immune system's ability to produce inflammation, B. It has no effect on the immune system, C. It activates a fight-flight-or-freeze response, D. It can suppress the immune system's ability to produce inflammation Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the primary use of corticosteroids in medications? Options: A. To build muscle, B. To regulate blood sugar levels, C. To fight allergic reactions and inflammation, D. To fight infection Correct Option: C
Question 8: What are the negative effects of long-term exposure to corticosteroids on the body? Options: A. Insomnia and lowered mood, B. Reduced immune system's ability to regenerate bone marrow and lymph nodes, C. Increased immune system's ability to fight infection, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the primary difference between intravenous or oral corticosteroids and inhalers or creams? Options: A. Intravenous or oral corticosteroids are more effective, B. Inhalers or creams are more effective, C. Intravenous or oral corticosteroids impact the whole body, while inhalers or creams impact only the affected organ affected by the condition, D. Intravenous or oral corticosteroids are more expensive Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the primary benefit of corticosteroids in the body? Options: A. To build muscle, B. To regulate blood sugar levels, C. To fight allergic reactions and inflammation, D. To fight infection Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ is about the percentage of a grizzly bear's diet that is vegetation, which is not related to the topic of steroids discussed in the transcript and the generated MCQs.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is closest to the ground truth MCQ in terms of being unrelated to the topic of steroids, I would say that none of the generated MCQs match. But if I really had to pick one, I would say Question 1, which is about the primary source of steroids in the human body, is the closest, but only because it's the first question and not because it matches the ground truth MCQ.

Index: None (or 1, if I really had to pick one)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do steroids enter the cell?
Options: A. They diffuse across the cell membrane., B. They bind to receptors on the surface of the cell membrane., C. They engulf the cell., D. Steroids don’t enter the cell.
Correct Option: A

Correct Option: A

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although Question 1 does not directly ask for the name of the body's primary steroid molecule, it does ask about the primary source of steroids in the human body. According to the transcript, cholesterol is the base molecule from which the body produces steroids, including cortisol, which is the body's primary steroid molecule. 

However, a more direct match would be a question that explicitly asks for the name of the body's primary steroid molecule. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the information provided, I would choose Question 1, with the understanding that it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Steroids: they’re infamous 
for their use in sports. But they’re also found in inhalers, 
creams to treat poison ivy and eczema, and shots to ease inflammation. The steroids in these medicines aren’t 
the same as the ones used to build muscle. In fact, they’re all based on 
yet another steroid— one our body produces naturally, 
and we can’t live without. Taking a step back, the reason 
there are so many different steroids is because the term refers to substances 
with a shared molecular structure, rather than shared effects on the body. Steroids can be naturally occurring 
or synthetic, but what all steroids have in common 
is a molecular structure that consists of a base of four rings 
made of 17 carbon atoms arranged in three hexagons 
and one pentagon. A molecule must contain 
this exact arrangement to be a steroid, though most also have side chains— additional atoms that can dramatically 
impact the molecule’s function. Steroids get their name 
from the fatty molecule cholesterol. In fact, our bodies make steroids 
out of cholesterol. That fatty cholesterol base 
means that steroids are able to cross fatty cell membranes 
and enter cells. Within the cell, they can directly 
influence gene expression and protein synthesis. This is different from many other types 
of signaling molecules, which can’t cross the cell membrane and have to create their effects 
from outside the cell, through more complicated pathways. So steroids can create their effects 
faster than those other molecules. Back to the steroids 
in anti-inflammatory medications: all of these are based on a naturally 
occurring steroid called cortisol. Cortisol is the body’s 
primary stress signal, and it has a huge range of functions. When we experience a stressor— anything from a fight with a friend, 
to spotting a bear, to an infection or low blood sugar— the brain reacts by sending a signal from 
the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland. The pituitary gland then sends a signal 
to the adrenal glands. The adrenal glands produce cortisol, 
and release some constantly. But when they receive the signal 
from the pituitary gland, they release a burst of cortisol, which spurs the body to generate 
more glucose for energy, decrease functions not immediately 
related to survival, like digestion, and can activate 
a fight-flight-or-freeze response. This is helpful in the short term, 
but can cause undesirable side effects like insomnia and lowered mood 
if they last too long. Cortisol also interacts 
with the immune system in complex ways— depending on the situation, it can increase or decrease 
certain immune functions. In the process of fighting infection, the immune system 
often creates inflammation. Cortisol suppresses the immune system’s 
ability to produce inflammation, which, again, 
can be useful in the short term. But too much cortisol 
can have negative impacts, like reducing the immune system’s ability 
to regenerate bone marrow and lymph nodes. To prevent levels 
from staying high for too long, cortisol suppresses the signal 
that causes the adrenal glands to release more cortisol. Medicinal corticosteroids channel 
cortisol’s effects on the immune system to fight allergic reactions, 
rashes, and asthma. All these things are forms 
of inflammation. There are many synthetic steroids 
that share the same basic mechanism: they enhance the body’s cortisol supply, which in turn shuts down 
the hyperactive immune responses that cause inflammation. These corticosteroids sneak into cells 
and can turn off the “fire alarm” by suppressing gene expression 
of inflammatory signals. The steroids in inhalers and creams impact
only the affected organ— the skin, or the lungs. Intravenous or oral versions, used 
to treat chronic autoimmune conditions like lupus or inflammatory bowel disease, 
impact the whole body. With these conditions, the body’s 
immune system attacks its own cells, a process analogous to a constant 
asthma attack or rash. A constant low dose of steroids can help keep this renegade
immune response under control— but because of the negative psychological 
and physiological effects of longterm exposure, higher doses are reserved 
for emergencies and flare-ups. While an asthma attack, poison ivy welts, 
and irritable bowel syndrome might seem totally unrelated, 
they all have something in common: an immune response 
that’s doing more harm than good. And while corticosteroids 
won’t give you giant muscles, they can be the body’s best defense 
against itself.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the primary function of cortisol?
Options: A. To suppress immunity and cope with stress, B. To enhance the fight/flight response at the expense of the freeze response, C. To boost allergy-type reactions, D. To promote sleep and restoration
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary source of steroids in the human body? Options: A. Fatty foods, B. Cholesterol, C. Sugar, D. Protein Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which part of the brain sends a signal to the pituitary gland in response to a stressor? Options: A. Hypothalamus, B. Pituitary gland, C. Adrenal glands, D. Brainstem Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the primary function of cortisol in the body's response to stress? Options: A. To build muscle, B. To regulate blood sugar levels, C. To respond to stress and trigger a fight-flight-or-freeze response, decrease non-essential functions, and interact with the immune system, D. To fight infection Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the effect of cortisol on the immune system in the short term? Options: A. It suppresses the immune system and reduces its ability to produce inflammation, B. It increases the immune system's ability to fight infection, C. It has no effect on the immune system, D. It activates a fight-flight-or-freeze response Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the primary difference between naturally occurring steroids and synthetic steroids? Options: A. Naturally occurring steroids are more effective, B. Synthetic steroids are more effective, C. Naturally occurring steroids are found in the body, while synthetic steroids are created in medications, D. Synthetic steroids are more expensive Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the effect of corticosteroids on the immune system in the short term? Options: A. It increases the immune system's ability to produce inflammation, B. It has no effect on the immune system, C. It activates a fight-flight-or-freeze response, D. It can suppress the immune system's ability to produce inflammation Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the primary use of corticosteroids in medications? Options: A. To build muscle, B. To regulate blood sugar levels, C. To fight allergic reactions and inflammation, D. To fight infection Correct Option: C
Question 8: What are the negative effects of long-term exposure to corticosteroids on the body? Options: A. Insomnia and lowered mood, B. Reduced immune system's ability to regenerate bone marrow and lymph nodes, C. Increased immune system's ability to fight infection, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the primary difference between intravenous or oral corticosteroids and inhalers or creams? Options: A. Intravenous or oral corticosteroids are more effective, B. Inhalers or creams are more effective, C. Intravenous or oral corticosteroids impact the whole body, while inhalers or creams impact only the affected organ affected by the condition, D. Intravenous or oral corticosteroids are more expensive Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the primary benefit of corticosteroids in the body? Options: A. To build muscle, B. To regulate blood sugar levels, C. To fight allergic reactions and inflammation, D. To fight infection Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions focus on the primary function of cortisol, and the correct options (A in the ground truth MCQ and C in Question 3) describe cortisol's role in responding to stress and interacting with the immune system.

Although the wording and options are not identical, Question 3 is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ among the provided generated MCQs.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

and irritable bowel syndrome might seem totally unrelated, 
they all have something in common: an immune response 
that’s doing more harm than good. And while corticosteroids 
won’t give you giant muscles, they can be the body’s best defense 
against itself.

Question: What do all steroids have in common?
Options: A. Structure, B. Function, C. Source, D. Indication
Correct Option: A

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 8
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Steroids: they’re infamous 
for their use in sports. But they’re also found in inhalers, 
creams to treat poison ivy and eczema, and shots to ease inflammation. The steroids in these medicines aren’t 
the same as the ones used to build muscle. In fact, they’re all based on 
yet another steroid— one our body produces naturally, 
and we can’t live without. Taking a step back, the reason 
there are so many different steroids is because the term refers to substances 
with a shared molecular structure, rather than shared effects on the body. Steroids can be naturally occurring 
or synthetic, but what all steroids have in common 
is a molecular structure that consists of a base of four rings 
made of 17 carbon atoms arranged in three hexagons 
and one pentagon. A molecule must contain 
this exact arrangement to be a steroid, though most also have side chains— additional atoms that can dramatically 
impact the molecule’s function. Steroids get their name 
from the fatty molecule cholesterol. In fact, our bodies make steroids 
out of cholesterol. That fatty cholesterol base 
means that steroids are able to cross fatty cell membranes 
and enter cells. Within the cell, they can directly 
influence gene expression and protein synthesis. This is different from many other types 
of signaling molecules, which can’t cross the cell membrane and have to create their effects 
from outside the cell, through more complicated pathways. So steroids can create their effects 
faster than those other molecules. Back to the steroids 
in anti-inflammatory medications: all of these are based on a naturally 
occurring steroid called cortisol. Cortisol is the body’s 
primary stress signal, and it has a huge range of functions. When we experience a stressor— anything from a fight with a friend, 
to spotting a bear, to an infection or low blood sugar— the brain reacts by sending a signal from 
the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland. The pituitary gland then sends a signal 
to the adrenal glands. The adrenal glands produce cortisol, 
and release some constantly. But when they receive the signal 
from the pituitary gland, they release a burst of cortisol, which spurs the body to generate 
more glucose for energy, decrease functions not immediately 
related to survival, like digestion, and can activate 
a fight-flight-or-freeze response. This is helpful in the short term, 
but can cause undesirable side effects like insomnia and lowered mood 
if they last too long. Cortisol also interacts 
with the immune system in complex ways— depending on the situation, it can increase or decrease 
certain immune functions. In the process of fighting infection, the immune system 
often creates inflammation. Cortisol suppresses the immune system’s 
ability to produce inflammation, which, again, 
can be useful in the short term. But too much cortisol 
can have negative impacts, like reducing the immune system’s ability 
to regenerate bone marrow and lymph nodes. To prevent levels 
from staying high for too long, cortisol suppresses the signal 
that causes the adrenal glands to release more cortisol. Medicinal corticosteroids channel 
cortisol’s effects on the immune system to fight allergic reactions, 
rashes, and asthma. All these things are forms 
of inflammation. There are many synthetic steroids 
that share the same basic mechanism: they enhance the body’s cortisol supply, which in turn shuts down 
the hyperactive immune responses that cause inflammation. These corticosteroids sneak into cells 
and can turn off the “fire alarm” by suppressing gene expression 
of inflammatory signals. The steroids in inhalers and creams impact
only the affected organ— the skin, or the lungs. Intravenous or oral versions, used 
to treat chronic autoimmune conditions like lupus or inflammatory bowel disease, 
impact the whole body. With these conditions, the body’s 
immune system attacks its own cells, a process analogous to a constant 
asthma attack or rash. A constant low dose of steroids can help keep this renegade
immune response under control— but because of the negative psychological 
and physiological effects of longterm exposure, higher doses are reserved 
for emergencies and flare-ups. While an asthma attack, poison ivy welts, 
and irritable bowel syndrome might seem totally unrelated, 
they all have something in common: an immune response 
that’s doing more harm than good. And while corticosteroids 
won’t give you giant muscles, they can be the body’s best defense 
against itself.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do steroids enter the cell?
Options: A. They diffuse across the cell membrane., B. They bind to receptors on the surface of the cell membrane., C. They engulf the cell., D. Steroids don’t enter the cell.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary source of steroids in the human body? Options: A. Fatty foods, B. Cholesterol, C. Sugar, D. Protein Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which part of the brain sends a signal to the pituitary gland in response to a stressor? Options: A. Hypothalamus, B. Pituitary gland, C. Adrenal glands, D. Brainstem Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the primary function of cortisol in the body's response to stress? Options: A. To build muscle, B. To regulate blood sugar levels, C. To respond to stress and trigger a fight-flight-or-freeze response, decrease non-essential functions, and interact with the immune system, D. To fight infection Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the effect of cortisol on the immune system in the short term? Options: A. It suppresses the immune system and reduces its ability to produce inflammation, B. It increases the immune system's ability to fight infection, C. It has no effect on the immune system, D. It activates a fight-flight-or-freeze response Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the primary difference between naturally occurring steroids and synthetic steroids? Options: A. Naturally occurring steroids are more effective, B. Synthetic steroids are more effective, C. Naturally occurring steroids are found in the body, while synthetic steroids are created in medications, D. Synthetic steroids are more expensive Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the effect of corticosteroids on the immune system in the short term? Options: A. It increases the immune system's ability to produce inflammation, B. It has no effect on the immune system, C. It activates a fight-flight-or-freeze response, D. It can suppress the immune system's ability to produce inflammation Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the primary use of corticosteroids in medications? Options: A. To build muscle, B. To regulate blood sugar levels, C. To fight allergic reactions and inflammation, D. To fight infection Correct Option: C
Question 8: What are the negative effects of long-term exposure to corticosteroids on the body? Options: A. Insomnia and lowered mood, B. Reduced immune system's ability to regenerate bone marrow and lymph nodes, C. Increased immune system's ability to fight infection, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the primary difference between intravenous or oral corticosteroids and inhalers or creams? Options: A. Intravenous or oral corticosteroids are more effective, B. Inhalers or creams are more effective, C. Intravenous or oral corticosteroids impact the whole body, while inhalers or creams impact only the affected organ affected by the condition, D. Intravenous or oral corticosteroids are more expensive Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the primary benefit of corticosteroids in the body? Options: A. To build muscle, B. To regulate blood sugar levels, C. To fight allergic reactions and inflammation, D. To fight infection Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the overall intent and topic, I would say that the most similar generated MCQ is not present in the list.

However, Question 1 talks about the source of steroids in the human body, which is cholesterol. This allows steroids to cross fatty cell membranes and enter cells. Therefore, while not directly matching the ground truth MCQ, Question 1 provides some relevant information.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match, but it's not a direct match.

Index: 1

often creates inflammation. Cortisol suppresses the immune system’s 
ability to produce inflammation, which, again, 
can be useful in the short term. But too much cortisol

from staying high for too long, cortisol suppresses the signal 
that causes the adrenal glands to release more cortisol. Medicinal corticosteroids channel

won’t give you giant muscles, they can be the body’s best defense 
against itself.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do steroids exert their effects in the cell?
Options: A. They bind to steroid receptors in the cell, which activates or suppresses gene expression in the nucleus., B. They induce a second-messenger cascade., C. They promote nerve firing in the brain and spinal cord, D. Steroids do not exert their effects in the cell, but rather, bind to proteins on the surface of the cell.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
meet the axolotl a Mexican salamander that scientists and the Internet alike love for their amazing ability to regenerate limbs and probably for that derpy smile hi I'm Danielle Defoe and you're watching Animal Logic axolotls are members of the ambystoma today family and are native to a very small region in Mexico axolotls were revered by Aztecs and their capital city was built on Islands and the lakes inhabited by the creatures but when the Spanish settled in 1521 they drained the lakes and built their city in its place a first step in driving axolotls towards extinction as Mexico City continues to grow and pollute the axolotl population is pushed further and further towards the brink today they can only be found in the wild in Mexico's Xochimilco link complex near Mexico City axolotls are unique among salamanders because they are Neotech which means that they reach adulthood without going through metamorphosis so they retain all of their juvenile features like us Millennials while most salamanders will grow up lose their gills in their dorsal fin as they get bigger and emerge onto land axolotls will keep their feathery external gills and remain underwater permanently it is extremely rare but sometimes axolotls will reach maturity and go through metamorphosis but even then they tend to keep to the water this has been accomplished in the lab by injecting them with a shot of iodine after which they more closely resemble their relatives the tiger salamander axolotls can get pretty big measuring around a foot or thirty centimeters long fully grown and they have long lives around 15 years in the wild but probably the most interesting thing about them is their intense ability to regenerate many amphibians do have the ability to regenerate but axolotls blow the competition out of the water not only can they perfectly and seemingly endlessly regenerate limbs but they can also regenerate their spinal cord jaw tail and skin all without scarring no matter how many times you cut off their limbs they'll grow back perfectly every single time and you wouldn't even be able to tell that you would cut off their limbs in the first place you could also even cut out a chunk of their spine come back in a month and a half and there'll be no worse for wear they are also a thousand times more resistant to cancer than any other animal it works like this after the amputation the cells at the site of the amputation lose their identity so instead of being skin cells or blood cells they become similar to stem cells called pluripotent cells and they're able to make any cell or tissue that the body would need to repair itself in this case they use the pleura in cells to generate all the cells and tissues needed to create new perfect limbs this phenomenon is a favorite among the scientific community for its potential to help burn victims amputees and even cancer victims scientists have experimented with modifying the genetic makeup of axolotls to include the green fluorescent protein which is the protein that makes many jellyfish bioluminescent well not just making axolotls look cooler the glowing protein allows scientists to see things inside the axolotls that they couldn't before for example they'll tag cancerous cells with the protein and then they can actually see how it spreads throughout their bodies even more interesting is that axolotls have plug-and-play body parts you can amputate one axolotls leg and place it in another axolotl and it'll attach itself it's especially interesting because you don't even need the whole limb just a few cells if you take cells from a neon axolotl and place them on an amputated body of an albino axolotl the albino axolotl will actually grow in neon limb since their skin is quite translucent you could actually watch the neon green bone grow out of an otherwise white axolotl this has led to some fairly morally compromising work in a study published in science magazine in 1968 scientists were able to successfully transplant an axolotl head onto the back of another axolotl one subject lived for 65 weeks after the operation with second head growing right along with the first head what animal should I check out next please let me know in the comments if you want to support the show and get episodes a week early you can do so by signing up for a free trial of the video streaming app love nature be sure to subscribe for new episodes of animal logic every other week right here on YouTube thanks for watching [Music] [Music]

Options: A. to renew, B. to begin, C. to regrow, D. to replace
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the scientific name of the family to which axolotls belong? Options: A. Ambystoma genus, B. Ambystoma family, C. Ambystoma mexicanum family, D. Ambystoma today family Correct Option: D
Question 2: Which of the following is a unique feature of axolotls compared to other salamanders? Options: A. They grow gills as they get bigger, B. They lose their gills and dorsal fin as they get bigger, C. They retain their juvenile features and do not undergo metamorphosis, D. They are able to regenerate their limbs perfectly Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the name of the protein that makes jellyfish bioluminescent, which scientists have experimented with modifying in axolotls? Options: A. Green fluorescent protein, B. Bioluminescent protein, C. Axolotl protein, D. Salamander protein Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the result of injecting an axolotl with a shot of iodine after amputating its limb? Options: A. The axolotl will grow a new limb, B. The axolotl will undergo metamorphosis, C. The axolotl will lose its ability to regenerate its limbs, D. The axolotl will more closely resemble its relatives, the tiger salamander Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the name of the complex near Mexico City where axolotls can only be found in the wild? Options: A. Xochimilco link complex, B. Mexico City complex, C. Axolotl complex, D. Salamander complex Correct Option: A
Question 6: How long can axolotls live in the wild? Options: A. 5 years, B. 10 years, C. 15 years, D. 20 years Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the result of cutting off an axolotl's limbs, and then waiting a month and a half? Options: A. The axolotl will have scarring, B. The axolotl will have lost its ability to regenerate its limbs, C. The axolotl will have grown new limbs, D. The axolotl will be no worse for wear Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the phenomenon that allows axolotls to regenerate their limbs perfectly? Options: A. The cells at the site of the amputation lose their identity and become similar to stem cells, B. The axolotl's body uses the pleura in cells to generate all the cells and tissues needed to create new limbs, C. The axolotl's body uses a special type of protein to regenerate its limbs, D. The axolotl's body uses a special type of cell to regenerate its limbs Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the result of transplanting an axolotl head onto the back of another axolotl? Options: A. The axolotl will die, B. The axolotl will undergo metamorphosis, C. The axolotl will grow a second head, D. The axolotl will lose its ability to regenerate its limbs Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the name of the video streaming app that offers episodes of Animal Logic a week early? Options: A. Love nature, B. Video streaming app, C. Animal Logic app, D. Salamander app Correct Option: A

**Question 8: What is the phenomenon that allows axolotls to regenerate their limbs perfectly?**

The axolotl's body uses the pleura in cells to generate all the cells and tissues needed to create new limbs, C. The axolotl's body uses a special type of protein to regenerate its limbs, D. The axolotl's body uses a special type of cell to regenerate its limbs

Correct Option: A

They lose their gills and dorsal fin as they get bigger, C. They retain their juvenile features and do not undergo metamorphosis, D. They are able to regenerate their limbs perfectly Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the name of the protein that makes jellyfish bioluminescent, which scientists have experimented with modifying in axolotls? Options: A. Green fluorescent protein, B. Bioluminescent protein, C. Axolotl protein, D. Salamander protein Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the result of injecting an axolotl with a shot of iodine after amputating its limb? Options: A. The axolotl will grow a new limb, B. The axolotl will undergo metamorphosis, C. The axolotl will lose its ability to regenerate its limbs, D. The axolotl will more closely resemble its relatives, the tiger salamander Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the name of the complex near Mexico City where axolotls can only be found in the wild? Options: A. Xochimilco link complex, B. Mexico City complex, C. Axolotl complex, D. Salamander complex Correct Option: A

Question 7: What is the result of cutting off an axolotl's limbs, and then waiting a month and a half? Options: A. The axolotl will have scarring, B. Question 8: What is the phenomenon that allows axolotls to regenerate their limbs perfectly? Options: A. The cells at the site of the amputation lose their identity and become similar to stem cells, B. The axolotl's body uses the pleura in cells to generate all the cells and tissues needed to create new limbs, C. The axolotl's body uses a special type of protein to regenerate its limbs, D. The axolotl's body uses a special type of cell to regenerate its limbs Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the result of transplanting an axolotl head onto the back of another axolotl? Options: A. The axolotl will die, B. The axolotl will undergo metamorphosis, C. The axolotl will grow a second head, D. The axolotl will lose its ability to regenerate its limbs Correct Option: C

continues to grow and pollute the axolotl population is pushed further and further towards the brink today they can only be found in the wild in Mexico's Xochimilco link complex near Mexico City axolotls are unique among salamanders because they are Neotech which means that they reach adulthood without going through metamorphosis so they retain all of their juvenile features like us Millennials while most salamanders will grow up lose their gills in their dorsal fin as they get bigger and emerge onto land axolotls will keep their feathery external gills and remain underwater permanently it is extremely rare but sometimes axolotls will reach maturity and go through metamorphosis but even then they tend to keep to the water this has been accomplished in the lab by injecting them with a shot of iodine after which they more closely resemble their relatives the tiger salamander axolotls can get pretty big measuring around a foot or thirty centimeters long fully grown and they have long lives around 15 years in the wild but probably the most interesting thing about them is their intense ability to regenerate many amphibians do have the ability to regenerate but axolotls blow the competition out of the water not only can they perfectly and seemingly endlessly regenerate limbs but they can also regenerate their spinal cord jaw tail and skin all without scarring no matter how many times you cut off their limbs they'll grow back perfectly every single time and you wouldn't even be able to tell that you would cut off their limbs in the first place you could also even cut out a chunk of their spine come back in a month and a half and there'll be no worse for wear they are also a thousand times more resistant to cancer than any other animal it works like this after the amputation the cells at the site of the amputation lose their identity so instead of being skin cells or blood cells they become similar to stem cells called pluripotent cells and they're able to make any cell or tissue that the body would need to repair itself in this case they use the pleura in cells to generate all the cells and tissues needed to create new perfect limbs this phenomenon is a favorite among the scientific community for its potential to help burn victims amputees and even cancer victims scientists have experimented with modifying the genetic makeup of axolotls to include the green fluorescent protein which is the protein that makes many jellyfish bioluminescent well not just making axolotls look cooler the glowing protein allows scientists to see things inside the axolotls that they couldn't before for example they'll tag cancerous cells with the protein and then they can actually see how it spreads throughout their bodies even more interesting is that axolotls have plug-and-play body parts you can amputate one axolotls leg and place it in another axolotl and it'll attach itself it's especially interesting because you don't even need the whole limb just a few cells if you take cells from a neon axolotl and place them on an amputated body of an albino axolotl the albino axolotl will actually grow in neon limb since their skin is quite translucent you could actually watch the neon green bone grow out of an otherwise white axolotl this has led to some fairly morally compromising work in a study published in science magazine
